item.title: ChatGPT (OpenAI)
item.description:
What is ChatGPT?

OpenAI’s flagship consumer AI product. GPT-4o is the engine — a multimodal model that handles text, images, audio, and code. The app layers on web browsing, DALL-E image generation, file analysis, and a plugin ecosystem. It’s the most feature-complete AI assistant available.

Who is it for?

  • Best for: Solo builders who want a single AI tool for everything — writing, research, coding, images
  • Not for: People who need the absolute best quality in one domain (Claude beats it for writing, Midjourney for images)
  • Solo builder score: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5)

What does it cost?

Plan Price What You Get
Free $0 GPT-4o (limited), GPT-4o-mini, DALL-E, browsing
Plus $20/mo More GPT-4o, voice mode, early features
Pro $200/mo Unlimited GPT-4o, o1-pro for heavy reasoning
API Pay-per-token GPT-4o ~$2.50/M input

Hidden costs: The $200/mo Pro tier exists and OpenAI keeps pushing features there first. Plus is fine for most people.

item.title: Claude (Anthropic)
item.description:
What is Claude?

Claude is Anthropic’s family of AI models. Opus is the powerhouse for deep reasoning, Sonnet is the daily driver balancing speed and quality, and Haiku is the fast/cheap option for simple tasks. For solo builders, you’ll live in Sonnet 90% of the time and pull out Opus when you need to think hard.

Who is it for?

  • Best for: Solo builders who need high-quality writing, complex coding help, or deep analysis
  • Not for: People who just need quick factual lookups (Perplexity is better) or image generation
  • Solo builder score: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

What does it cost?

Plan Price What You Get
Free $0 Limited Sonnet messages, basic features
Pro $20/mo More Sonnet, some Opus, Projects, longer context
API Pay-per-token Sonnet ~$3/M input, Opus ~$15/M input

Hidden costs: Pro usage caps aren’t published — you’ll hit them during heavy work sessions. API is more predictable but requires technical setup.

item.title: Gemini (Google)
item.description:
What is Gemini?

Google’s AI platform, powered by the Gemini model family. The killer feature is context — 1M+ tokens means you can feed it entire books, codebases, or research papers. Comes with built-in Google Search, image generation (Imagen), and tight integration with Google Workspace.

Who is it for?

  • Best for: Researchers, content creators processing large documents, anyone in Google’s ecosystem
  • Not for: People who need the best writing quality (Claude) or the most versatile tool (ChatGPT)
  • Solo builder score: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5)

What does it cost?

Plan Price What You Get
Free $0 Gemini Pro, image gen, web search, generous limits
Advanced $20/mo 1M+ context, Workspace integration, Gemini Ultra
API Pay-per-token Pro: free tier available, Ultra from ~$1.25/M input

Hidden costs: The $20/mo bundles with Google One (2TB storage), which is actually decent value if you need cloud storage anyway.

item.title: Notion AI
item.description:
What is Notion AI?

An AI layer built into Notion’s workspace app. It can draft content, summarize pages, brainstorm ideas, extract action items, and answer questions about your workspace. It works inline — highlight text, ask AI to improve it, done.

Who is it for?

  • Best for: Existing heavy Notion users who want AI without leaving their workspace
  • Not for: Anyone not already using Notion — don’t adopt Notion just for the AI
  • Solo builder score: ⭐⭐⭐☆☆ (3/5)

What does it cost?

Plan Price What You Get
Free + AI Can’t AI requires paid plan
Plus + AI $18/mo total Notion workspace + unlimited AI
Business + AI $25/mo total Team features + AI

Hidden costs: You’re paying for Notion AND the AI. If you’re not getting value from Notion itself, this is expensive for what the AI adds.

item.title: The Content Machine Stack
item.description:
The Content Machine Stack

One person. Blog posts, social media, newsletters, and video — all shipping weekly. This stack turns a solo creator into a content studio by chaining AI writing, image generation, voice synthesis, and a programmable publishing layer.

Who It’s For

  • Best for: Solo creators, indie bloggers, newsletter operators, and personal brand builders who need to produce across multiple formats without a team.
  • Not for: Large editorial teams with existing workflows, or creators who need photorealistic brand photography (you’ll want a real camera for that).

The Tools

Tool Role Cost
Claude Writing — drafts, editing, repurposing $20/mo (Pro)
Stable Diffusion (local) or Midjourney Image generation — thumbnails, illustrations, social graphics $0 (local) or $10/mo
ElevenLabs Voiceover — narration, audiograms, podcast clips $5–22/mo
Cursor Publishing automation — custom scripts, site updates $0–20/mo

How They Connect

Idea / Outline
 │
 ▼
 ┌────────┐
 │ Claude │ → Blog post, newsletter draft, social threads, video script
 └───┬────┘
 │
 ├──────────────────┐
 ▼ ▼
┌──────────────┐ ┌───────────┐
│ Stable Diff/ │ │ ElevenLabs│ → Voiceover from script
│ Midjourney │ └───────────┘
│ → Images │
└──────────────┘
 │ │
 └────────┬─────────┘
 ▼
 ┌──────────┐
 │ Cursor │ → Assemble, format, publish (site/newsletter/social)
 └──────────┘

Total Monthly Cost

Tier Monthly Cost
Budget (SD local + Claude + ElevenLabs Starter) ~$25/mo
Standard (Midjourney + Claude Pro + ElevenLabs) ~$52/mo
Full send (all paid tiers) ~$80/mo

Freedom Score: ⭐⭐⭐⭐☆ (4/5)

  • Why 4: You own your content, can swap any tool, and the local image generation option means no vendor lock-in for visuals. Claude and ElevenLabs are cloud-dependent, which docks a point.
  • Lock-in risk: Low. All outputs are standard formats (text, PNG, MP3). Nothing traps you.

Getting Started (This Afternoon)

  1. Sign up for Claude Pro ($20/mo). Create a project with your brand voice guidelines and sample content.
  2. Set up image generation. Easiest: Midjourney ($10/mo). Most free: install ComfyUI + Stable Diffusion locally.
  3. Create an ElevenLabs account. Clone your voice or pick a stock voice. Test with a 60-second script.
  4. Open Cursor. Build a simple publishing script — even just a markdown-to-HTML converter that drops files into your site’s content folder.
  5. Run your first piece through the full pipeline. Idea → Claude draft → generate 2-3 images → record voiceover → publish. Time it. You’ll be shocked.

Expected output: 3-5 blog posts/week, daily social content, weekly newsletter, optional audio versions of everything. One person.

item.title: Tools for AI-Powered Research
item.description:
Tools for AI-Powered Research

Use AI to research faster, synthesize information from multiple sources, and produce well-sourced analysis.

Deep Research & Synthesis

  • Claude — Best for long-form analysis and synthesis. 200K token context window lets you feed entire documents and get comprehensive summaries. Projects feature stores research context across conversations.
  • Kimi K2.5 — Massive context window for processing large documents. Strong at multi-source synthesis.
  • Perplexity AI — AI search engine that cites its sources. Good for initial research and fact-finding. Free tier is useful; Pro unlocks more powerful models.

Document Processing

  • Whisper (local) — Transcribe interviews, podcasts, lectures, and meetings. Run locally for free with Ollama.
  • NotebookLM (Google) — Upload documents and chat with them. Auto-generates summaries, FAQs, and audio overviews.

Knowledge Management

  • Obsidian — Local-first note-taking with bidirectional linking. Build a personal knowledge graph from your research. Pairs beautifully with Ollama for local AI chat about your notes.
  • Logseq — Open-source alternative to Obsidian. Outline-based. Good for daily journals and block-level references.

Data Analysis

  • Claude — Upload CSVs and get analysis, charts, and insights. Artifacts feature renders visualizations inline.
  • Julius AI — Purpose-built for data analysis. Upload spreadsheets, ask questions in plain English, get charts and statistical analysis.

Citation & Writing

  • Zotero — Free, open-source reference manager. Essential for academic or well-sourced writing.
  • Claude — Draft research reports, literature reviews, and analysis from your collected sources.

Recommended Workflow

  1. Discover — Use Perplexity to survey a topic and collect initial sources
  2. Collect — Save sources to Zotero, transcribe audio with Whisper
  3. Process — Feed documents to Claude or Kimi for synthesis and analysis
  4. Connect — Store insights in Obsidian, link related concepts
  5. Produce — Draft final output with Claude, citing your sources

item.title: Tools for Newsletter Automation
item.description:
Tools for Newsletter Automation

Build and run a newsletter with AI handling the heavy lifting — research, writing, formatting, and scheduling.

Writing & Research

  • Claude — Draft full newsletter editions from bullet points or topic prompts. Excellent at maintaining consistent voice across issues. Use Projects to store your style guide and past editions.
  • Kimi K2.5 — Great for research-heavy newsletters. Feed it multiple sources and get synthesized summaries.

Design & Formatting

  • Cursor — Build custom newsletter templates in HTML/CSS. Automate formatting with scripts that convert markdown drafts to email-ready HTML.

Voiceover (Audio Newsletters)

  • ElevenLabs — Turn your newsletter into a podcast-style audio version. Growing trend — readers love having an audio option.

Sending & Management

  • Beehiiv — Newsletter platform with free tier up to 2,500 subscribers. Built-in analytics, referral program, and monetization.
  • ConvertKit (Kit) — Creator-focused email platform. Visual automations, tagging, segmentation.
  • Buttondown — Minimal, markdown-first newsletter tool. Great for developers and writers who want simplicity.

Automation & Scheduling

  • Zapier / Make — Connect your writing tools to your sending platform. Auto-publish drafts on a schedule.
  • Cursor — Build custom automation scripts: RSS-to-newsletter, auto-curate links, format and schedule sends via API.

Recommended Workflow

  1. Curate topics throughout the week (Obsidian or a simple note)
  2. Feed topics to Claude → get a full draft
  3. Edit in 15 minutes (your voice, your opinions — AI does the heavy lifting)
  4. Format with your template
  5. Schedule send in Beehiiv/ConvertKit
  6. Optionally generate audio version with ElevenLabs

Time per issue: 45-90 minutes instead of 4+ hours.
